Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENM0295 - Personalised medicine","description":"

The last 10-15 years have yielded significant and rapid advances in our understanding of the human genome, and the impact on human health & clinical practice is already being widely felt. This course will discuss both the potential benefits and possible controversies surrounding the genetic revolution as it relates to healthcare. Students will learn how genetic testing is currently used to guide treatment across a range of diseases including cancer, neurological diseases, autoimmune disorders, cardiovascular disease, and respiratory disease. In addition, students will explore the power of genetics to impact disease prevention and diagnosis, and the social, legal, political and ethical implications of this new knowledge.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e3a1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Discussion Forums","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will contribute to online discussion forums on the course Moodle site. Contributions must be considered and respectful. Students should aim to make a minimum of one post per week to the discussion forum during the term (i.e. at least 10 posts), and comment on another student’s post at least once per lecture/tutorial topic (i.e. at least 5 responses). As a guide, posts should be between 100-200 words and may include supportive references or websites. At the end of the term tudents will submit their 4 best forum posts and their best student response for assessment. No formal feedback will be provided beyond the contribution of the tutors to the online forum discussions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"27a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"aba1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aba1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e7a1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e7a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1fa1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will prepare and present a short oral presentation on an area of controversy in personalised medicine. This talk will be given in a designated tutorial class and students will receive feedback from tutors and other students. The presentation will be three minutes long, and if students choose to use PowerPoint, a maximum of three slides is allowed. Presentations will be followed by one minutes of questions. Students may select a topic from the list below or suggest their own topic. Each topic may only be presented by one student in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"27a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"aba1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e7a1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"43a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

At the end of the term students will present an oral presentation as a group on the same topic as their individual essay. This can be in delivered as a traditional lecture, debate, panel discussion or video. Students will be given the choice of format, and allowed time to meet as a group and prepare in their tutorials. Each group will receive a mark for their presentation, no formal feedback will be provided.
 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"27a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"aba1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aba1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e7a1257bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e7a1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9ba1e17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will work in small groups (5-6 students) on a project on one topic in the area of personalised medicine. Students can select their own topic area. Students will individually write a comprehensive 1,500 word report on the topic. Students can write a traditional essay or choose to write from a specific viewpoint (e.g. patient, doctor, health minister, genetic counsellor, conservative newspaper columnist). Students will have the opportunity to receive direction and guidance from course tutors during the tutorial sessions. Marks and feedback will be provided via Moodle.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENM0510 - Making News: Engaging the Media","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


This exciting course provides an introductory overview of contemporary trends in mass media and the key concepts necessary to understand what media is and how to contextualise news. The course has a specific focus on engaging with media to promote health and social wellness issues, highlight health issues and challenges through media advocacy, and to raise awareness and mobilise for social change. The course provides opportunities to engage with inspirational people from across all aspects of media, from print to social media and in between. The current Australian media landscape is examined through analysis of readings and special guest lectures from different media outlets providing a close insight into their industry, how to best choose the best channel and how to tailor the message for it. The second half of the course gives practical instruction and training on developing content for mass media, providing the students with tools to tailor content, to writing for media, planning, developing a strategy and managing journalists.

Australia spends $100 billion a year on health care and its average health indicators are among the best in the world. None the less, some Australians are much less healthy than others. In exploring the question of why this is so, the course examines concepts of power and health in society and how the distribution of wealth is reflected in the health status of different social classes and ethnic groups. It also traces trends in understandings of health and public health, the challenge of alternative models of health, how the internet is bringing about changes in power relationships in the health field and explores controversies over childbirth. For further Information see SPHCM General Education Timetables

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENM0519 - Pandemics, Power and Society","description":"

Pandemics, and infectious disease outbreaks more generally, are a growing source of public concern and controversy. The media are continually accused of exaggerating concerns, and the actions of public health authorities are constantly publically scrutinised. What questions should the public be asking of public health responses to infectious disease, and what can public health authorities do to connect with the general public and gain their trust? This course will introduce you to social scientific research with relevance to the social and political aspects of infectious disease control. You will be introduced to some key social scientific concepts used to understand the challenges public health authorities face in trying to garner public trust; and you will be introduced to social scientific research that can inform responses to actual and potential pandemics. You will draw on these concepts and this research to critically engage with media and public discussion of pandemics.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"55b329bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961919","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Building tutorial discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

You are not being assessed on simply turning up to the tutorials. Simply being there is not enough to pass this assessment component; the assessment criteria are quite specific. You are being assessed on the following marking criteria:

  • Do your tutorial contributions help the group to develop an understanding of WHAT the author is saying (through sharing your understanding, through asking clear questions about the parts you do not understand, through thinking through possible answers to those questions and the implications of those answers)
  • Do you explain your understanding of the relevance of the paper and do you explore possible connections with other readings
  • Do you identify strengths and weaknesses in the paper AND explain your reasons for identifying those strengths/weaknesses
  • Do you relate your ideas to those being articulated by others – both others in the group discussions and other authors we are reading in this course
  • Do you facilitate the articulation of other people’s ideas, by listening, asking them to explain what you cannot follow, and by making connections between what you are hearing and the course material

Between weeks 5 and 8 you will receive indicative feedback about your contributions to the development of the discussion so you get a sense of what grade you might be getting based on participation so far, and an idea of where you might improve.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"59b329bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cdb329bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09b329bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Choose one reading from Module 1 (either XXX or XXX) and write a short (800 words max) critical summary of the position being developed by the author/s. Do not write a summary of the lectures, focus on:

  1. Giving a clear account of the main argument being developed in your chosen paper, and the building blocks used by the author/s to develop their position (do not use dot points, focus on showing your understanding of the original paper and providing a context for your critical analysis of it and of the discussion we have of it);
  2. Making a clear statement about what you find interesting about the main argument, and the particular point, idea or argument on which you are going to focus your critical engagement;
  3. Articulation and development of your position on this point; you are advised to draw on supporting material (other readings for this course or beyond, 1-2 references) in the development of your position;
  4. a short conclusion where you explain on the convergences and/or divergences between your position and that of the original paper and reflect on their implications.

Use the following structure: 

  1. Summary of the paper (suggest 300 words maximum)
  2. An explanation of your interest in the main argument of the paper, and your clearly developed critique of the paper (suggest 300 words maximum)
  3. Conclusion, reflecting on the convergences/divergences between the position being developed in the paper and your own position (suggest 100 words maximum)
  4. References (suggest 100 words maximum)

Marking criteria

  • Is the critical summary well structured, succinct, written lucidly and advancing a coherent argument (consider grammar and spelling)? Does the critical summary include full bibliographic information (APA)? Is the conclusion clearly stated? (5)
  • Does the summary of the chosen paper demonstrate your comprehension of the main argument being put forward in the paper, and the building blocks of this argument? (10)
  • Does your critical engagement with the paper demonstrate your comprehension of what the paper is aiming to do, does it include an explanation of the particular focus you are taking? Is your position well explained and supported (through careful development and by drawing on broader literature where you can)? (10)
  • In concluding, do you critically reflect on the position you are putting forward? (5)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"59b329bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cdb329bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4b3e5bfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The final essay is to be no longer than 2000 words, including references.

You will be given a selection of essay questions in week 6.

Essay topics will focus on particular instances of media coverage of pandemics or infectious disease outbreaks and the set essay questions will ask you to critically evaluate the (explicit and implicit) account of the social and political challenges public health faces in the media, drawing on the course material.

Assessment criteria for essay:

Your essay will be marked according to the following criteria:

  1. Is the position you are going to develop in the essay clearly stated and introduced at the beginning? (5)
  2. Do you present key social scientific concepts clearly and use them appropriately? (10)
  3. Does the essay evidence thorough and insightful use of the literature? Have you drawn upon available theory and insights from others (if others in the tutorials have given you good ideas use them and acknowledge them)? (10)
  4. Analysis.  Are the ideas you introduce and develop relevant to the question? Are you making a coherent argument (rather than presenting a series of divergent ideas)? Is the argument lucid and well supported? Does the essay include evidence of your own analysis? (10)
  5. Description and presentation: Is the work well-set out and written in clear and coherent English, with appropriate use of headings and sub-headings and signposting of the development of your argument? (10)
  6. Referencing: Is the work adequately and competently referenced? You are asked to use APA referencing (see below for links to a guide AND links to downloading endnote) but if you are already at home with another system and prefer to use it that is fine. An inconsistently referenced essay will drop a grade. (5)

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


Do you visualise a society without social problems? Do you have a curiosity about how to make difference by offering solution(s) for social problems? Do you have the zeal to be a socially responsible entrepreneur in the healthcare settings?


The emerging field of social business comes against the backdrop of unleashing human ingenuity in which the market-driven approach for solving social problem (s) in health, education, environment etc stands as the primary objective. In this course, we will develop the skills and perspective that enable you to identify and understand a social problem, to generate creative ideas to address it, and to build a realistic social business plan.


The focus in the class shifts from the theoretical understanding of social business to the practical approach of planning, organising, leading and monitoring a social business. You will explore case studies, scenerious and real-time experiences from a largest Global academic and professional network of social business (i.e. Noble Laureate Professor Yunus Social business in 16 countries, 31 universities, 12 academic programs) and meet successful social business entrepreneurs to move your social business plan to market.

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.

Do you visualise a society without social problems? Do you have a curiosity about how to make difference by offering solution(s) for social problems? Do you have the zeal to be a socially responsible entrepreneur in the healthcare settings?

The emerging field of social business comes against the backdrop of unleashing human ingenuity in which the market-driven approach for solving social problem (s) in health, education, environment etc stands as the primary objective. In this course, we will develop the skills and perspective that enable you to identify and understand a social problem, to generate creative ideas to address it, and to build a realistic social business plan.

The focus in the class shifts from the theoretical understanding of social business to the practical approach of planning, organising, leading and monitoring a social business. You will explore case studies, scenerious and real-time experiences from a largest Global academic and professional network of social business (i.e. Noble Laureate Professor Yunus Social business in 16 countries, 31 universities, 12 academic programs) and meet successful social business entrepreneurs to move your social business plan to market.
contentlets.title: Social Business for Public Health

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENM0703 - Concepts of Physical Activity, Exercise and Health","description":"

In this course, you will learn about how the human body moves and the relationships between physical activity or inactivity and health and disease.


There is confusing information in our modern world regarding physical activity and health. This course uses evidence-based medicine to explain physical activity-related subjects using the latest scientific evidence. Some topics covered include: the physiology of movement, effects of physical activity on the body, physical activity public health, physical activity requirements and needs for different population groups, and use of technology.


You will be encouraged to look at your movement habits - and those of the wider public - in a new way that will hopefully improve your health (and that of your loved ones) now, and in the years to come.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"81a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961966","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lifestyle change project (20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will start a lifestyle change program focusing on physical activity levels. They will monitor their progress and write a reflective piece documenting the process and discussing the outcomes Students are expected to support their writing with a wide range of quality literature.

A mark and written feedback will be given via Moodle.

Due: Mid-term

There are weekly quizzes over the 10 weeks of term, i.e. 10 quizzes. Students will be assessed on their understanding of the course content. There will be 10 multiple-choice questions in each quiz (each question is worth 0.2%). Quizzes are time-limited (15 minutes). Students can only make 1 attempt per quiz and will be assessed on the accuracy of their answers.

Questions will be based on material covered in lectures (including preparation lessons/videos and post-lecture readings/activities) and tutorials on a week-by-week basis. Since there is 1 lecture and 1 tutorial each week, 1 quiz will cover 1 lecture (including preparation lesson/s and post-lecture readings/activities) and 1 tutorial. 

Feedback is provided weekly via grades and answers to questions. 

Due: Weekly

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0da1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"74a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961954","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"85a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b0a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cda1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aca1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation (20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

In groups, students will organise a tutorial presentation where they will analyse a chosen aspect of physical activity. Students are expected to support their work by using a wide range of quality literature.

Students will receive an individual performance mark, a group performance mark, and written feedback from their tutor (via Moodle).

Due: During tutorials in final weeks of term

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0da1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"74a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961954","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"85a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b0a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cda1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bca1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Capstone paper (40%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The capstone paper is a culmination of student learning over the term. Students will have the choice to select 1 of 2 options for the capstone paper. Option A: Students are to analyse the relationship between their (future) chosen industry and physical activity. How can the discipline improve physical activity levels in people? An example is walkable cities and green spaces (Faculty of the Built Environment). Option B: Students are to analyse a physical activity public health issue, discussing the relationship between physical activity and a particular disease.

Students are expected to support their writing with a wide range of quality literature.

Feedback - in the form of a mark and written information - will be provided to and from a peer (5% of 40%) and from an academic marker (35% of 40%), both via Moodle.

Due: In a later week in term

contentlets.description:
In this course, you will learn about how the human body moves and the relationships between physical activity or inactivity and health and disease.

There is confusing information in our modern world regarding physical activity and health. This course uses evidence-based medicine to explain physical activity-related subjects using the latest scientific evidence. Some topics covered include: the physiology of movement, effects of physical activity on the body, physical activity public health, physical activity requirements and needs for different population groups, and use of technology.

You will be encouraged to look at your movement habits - and those of the wider public - in a new way that will hopefully improve your health (and that of your loved ones) now, and in the years to come.
contentlets.title: Concepts of Physical Activity, Exercise and Health

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENM0707 - Nutrition and Health","description":"

Nutrition is relevant to everybody, every day. What, how and why you eat and drink are questions you may not have contemplated in any depth, but adequate nutrition is key to both good physical and mental health. In exploring the mechanisms and determinants of nutrition behaviours, this course offers an opportunity to understand what nutrients your body needs, how your body processes nutrients, how to analyse your own diet, and how poor nutrition can influence individual and population health. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c6a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation (20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

In groups, students will organise a tutorial presentation where they will deconstruct a current contested nutrition topic, and teach their fellow students the cause and consequences of using or following said topic. Students are expected to support their work by using a wide range of quality literature.

Students will receive an individual performance mark, a group performance mark, and written feedback from their tutor (via Moodle).

Due: During tutorials in final weeks of term

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"caa1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f5a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"61a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes (10 x 2% = 20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

There are weekly quizzes over the 10 weeks of term, i.e. 10 quizzes. Students will be assessed on their understanding of the course content. There will be 10 multiple-choice questions in each quiz (each question is worth 0.2%). Quizzes are time-limited (15 minutes). Students can only make 1 attempt per quiz and will be assessed on the accuracy of their answers.

Questions will be based on material covered in lectures (including preparation lessons/videos and post-lecture readings/activities) and tutorials on a week-by-week basis. Since there is 1 lecture and 1 tutorial each week, 1 quiz will cover 1 lecture (including preparation lesson/s and post-lecture readings/activities) and 1 tutorial. 

Feedback is provided weekly via grades and answers to questions. 

Due: Weekly

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"caa1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f5a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Capstone paper (40%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The capstone paper is a culmination of student learning over the term. Students will have the choice to select 1 of 2 options for the capstone paper. Option A: Students are to analyse the relationship between their (future) chosen industry and nutrition, food and eating. An example is the impact of nutrition on eye health, and/or impact of poor eye health on eating habits (School of Optometry and Vision Science). Option B: Students are to analyse a nutrition public health issue, discussing the relationship between nutrition, food and eating, and a particular disease (e.g. cancer) or socio-environmental issue (e.g. food waste). 

Students are expected to support their writing with a wide range of quality literature.

Feedback - in the form of a mark and written information - will be provided to and from a peer (5% of 40%) and from an academic marker (35% of 40%), both via Moodle.

Due: In a later week in term

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"caa1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f5a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9a1a17bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Nutrition self-reflection project (20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are to monitor their dietary intake using appropriate assessment tools, and analyse the influences and effects of their current eating habits. Students are expected to support their writing with a wide range of quality literature.

A mark and written feedback will be given via Moodle.

Due: Mid-term

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENM0708 - Principles of Health Education & Behaviour Change","description":"

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.


This is a six-unit general education course. It is designed to provide students from a range of disciplines with: (1) an understanding of theories and models of behaviour change; and (2) the opportunity to practice skills and strategies that impact health behavioural change. Particular emphasis is placed on improving competency in communication and decision-making to assist self and others with health concerns. With progressthrough the course, students will develop a more sophisticated level of knowledge, attitudes, values, and skills to address health issues and play an active role in enhancing their own health and that of their community. More specifically, students will gain the social, problem-solving, and communication skills necessary to manage their own health in a variety of situations.  This course is action-oriented; as such, students will be encouraged to implement and evaluate their own lifestyle choices and inspire others to optimise their wellbeing. Classes will combine lecture, discussion of the readings, case studies, real-life scenarios, presentations, small group exercises, and audiovisual materials.

As an internal student you will be assessed on your ongoing contribution to class discussion and active participation in the course. This means you will be expected to come to class prepared (i.e. having read and thought about assigned papers or topis) and be ready to present your ideas and engage in meaningful discussion with your fellow students and lecturers. As an external student you will be assessed on your participation in your online group discussions. This means that you need to demonstrate an ongoing engagement with ideas and debates across the semester. It is not a matter of simply being online each week but rather contributing meaningfully and thoughtfully with others in your online group each week.


Assessment criteria for internal students’ participation:

You are not being assessed on simply turning up to class. Of course, you need to be there to participate, but the assessment criteria are quite specific. Simply being there is not enough to pass this assessment component. Your contributions to the development of the class/group discussion will be assessed as follows:

• Does your participation contribute to the group’s development of new understandings based on the weekly readings and lectures?

• Do you contribute respectfully and meaningfully to debates and ideas presented within the class/group?

• Do you contribute to discussion by identifying possible strengths and weaknesses in the material/reading being discussed and by explaining your reasons for identifying those strengths/weaknesses?

• Do you relate your own ideas to those being articulated by others (both others in the group discussions and other authors we are reading in this course)?

• Do you facilitate the articulation of other people’s ideas, by engaging with their contribution, by asking them to explain what you cannot follow, and by making connections between others' ideas and the course material?

Assessment criteria for external students’ participation:

You are not being assessed on simply logging into Moodle. Of course, you need to be there to participate. Your contributions to the development of the class/group discussion will be assessed by the following criteria outlined Table below . The rating scale ranges from 1 to 4 with 1 being indicative of student participation which is less than acceptable for the development of a progressive learning group. A score of 4 in any category represents the attainment of the highest standard of participation and reflects a bonafide contribution to the learning community.

Behaviour Change Project: This assignment requires you to: (1) analyse key components of a health behaviour, based on a health behaviour model; and (2) develop an intervention for one of the components.

 

Task Description

Interview a person about a health behaviour, which you want to improve or change. Inform the interviewee that all of his/her information will be kept confidential and anonymous. Ask permission to record the interview. To do this project:

·         1. Identify a health behaviour that you want to improve or change (e.g., physical activity, tobacco use, unhealthy diet, alcohol use, etc.)

·         2. Select a health behaviour model discussed during the course that you consider relevant to your project.

·         3. Guided by the selected health behaviour model, develop interview questions to understand the interviewee’s lifestyle choices. For example, if you have selected the health belief model, the questions might include questions about:

o   Perceived threat, including perceived susceptibilities and severities

o   Modifying factors

o   Cues to action

o   Self-efficacy

·         4. Conduct and record the interview

·         5. Analyse the recorded interview based on the selected model. List each construct of the model and identify the relevant information gathered from your interviewee. For example, if you have selected the health belief model, findings relevant to the perceived threat might be presented as follows:

o   Perceived threats:

§  The interviewee is minimally aware of the relationship between a sedentary lifestyle and increased risk of cardiovascular disease and some cancers

§  The interviewee feels good right now and does not feel at risk of future health problems

§  The interviewee’s father has high blood pressure and early evidence of heart disease

·         6. Discuss the main factors that influence the person’s health behaviour. Substantiate this discussion with quotes from the interview; your argument should be clear and concise.

·         7. Select one component of the health behaviour that requires change and develop an educational intervention to modify it. The intervention should clearly address the interviewee’s situation. For example, if you have chosen the health belief model and want to  address  the interviewee’s perceived threat, the intervention should address interviewee’s misunderstanding or unawareness of perceived susceptibilities and severities. The educational content of the intervention should be well-summarised and brief.

·         8. Identify and discuss an appropriate communication channel to deliver the intervention to the interviewee. The selected channel should be well-justified and  align with the  interviewee’s situation.

 

Your assignment should have the following parts:

1.      Literature: A brief literature review of the health behaviour, which you have selected to improve or change (e.g., physical activity, tobacco use, unhealthy diet, alcohol use, etc.) and the health behaviour model you have selected to guide your project. This section should address: (1) why the health behaviour is important; and (2) how the selected health behaviour model can contribute to the management / prevention of the health behaviour.

Note: The literature should not include any description of the model.

2.      Method: This section should include a brief description of how the interview was conducted.

3.      Result: The interviewee’s demographic information (e.g., age, sex, highest educational level, etc.) and a summary of key findings

4.      Discussion: Bring together the relevant information about the health behaviour, clearly guided by the selected health model.

5.      Educational intervention and communication channel: The educational content, which you have developed to modify or change one of the components of the health behaviour, followed by your justification of using a particular communication channel to delivery your educational message should be reported in this section.

 

Presenting and submitting the assignment

 

Present your assignment as an essay, using the accepted format for publishable papers (see learning centre for further assistance). Do not provide a list of texts corresponding to points in the assignment outline. The total word count for the essay should not exceed 1,500 words, excluding references. The word count must be indicated on the cover sheet. Essays over the word limit will receive a lower grade.


Assessment Criteria

The assignment will be marked according to the following criteria:

·         How well is the assignment structured and presented?

Papers are to be presented in a formal structure, as you would for submission to a professional journal, for example. They will be assessed for clarity (clear, simple, grammatical language, spelling, terms explained), logical structure, coherent and logical argument, appropriate use of subheadings, clear layout, etc.

·         How effectively did you draw on the literature and the interview to identify the patient’s health beliefs?

·         How well did you critically consider the values and assumptions that underlie the interviewee’s health beliefs?

 

·         How well did you critically consider the values and assumptions that underlie your assessment practice in relation to influencing the interviewee’s health beliefs and behaviours?

Critical review of a health education intervention

Your group needs to select a health education intervention as your topic for analysis and presentation. You will be assessed for both the material your group develops, and for how creatively you present this material. Within your group, whether online or campus-based, you are required to share the tasks of finding, analysing, and interpreting the health education intervention.

 

Task Description

1.      Select one of the following behavioural risk factors:

a.       Sedentary lifestyle (physical activity)

b.      Tobacco use

c.       Unhealthy diet (obesity)

d.      Alcohol use

2.      Select an academic, refereed article on a health education intervention that has been implemented and which invites people to take responsibility for their own health. Do not choose an intervention that needs to be delivered by healthcare professionals or services (e.g., immunisation, screening, etc.). The intervention can be well or poorly designed – this is because you are required to discuss your understanding of the principles of health education and health behaviour models explored in this course.

3.      Briefly describe the intervention and then critically analyse it. Consider:

a.       Its suitability for its target group

b.      The setting

c.       Participant numbers

d.      Use of theory and/or models

e.       Its evaluation (if appropriate)

4.      Develop and support your critique by drawing on a minimum of TEN relevant academic refereed articles. Discuss:

a.       How well the intervention reflects the health education principles and health behaviour models explored in this course, justified by reference to the literature. If the intervention does not reflect the health education principles and health behaviour models:

                                                               i.      Discuss the associated implications, with reference to the literature

                                                             ii.      Suggest how the intervention might have been improved with reference to health education principles and/or health behaviour models

b.      The strengths and limitations of the intervention with reference to the literature

 

Presenting and submitting the assignment

INTERNAL

This is a 15-minute oral presentation in class, supported by a PowerPoint slide presentation or other creative format. The audience is your peers. You must choose how many of the group will participate in the oral presentation. But all members should: contribute to the research; develop the presentation; and be prepared to answer questions.

 

EXTERNAL

 

Each online group will post a presentation in the form of a PowerPoint slide presentation or other creative format on your own Moodle group space. The Course Convenor will be responsible for disseminating this to the other external groups via Moodle. For more detail on the slides, you can add explanations in the notes section of the PowerPoint slides.


Assessment Criteria

Thirty (out of 40) percentage points will be allocated for how well your group:

·         Described the intervention

·         Critically reflected on the values and assumptions that justified its development

·         Explained the conceptual and theoretical underpinnings

·         Discussed the advantages and disadvantages of the intervention

·         Discussed the implementation challenges

·         Discussed the appropriateness of the intervention to promote health within the context it was used

·         Discussed the way the intervention accounts for the needs and preferences of the target audience

·         Discussed the extent to which the intervention followed a planning process, and the connections between its objectives and its activities

 

Ten (out of 40) percentage points will be allocated for the presentation, including:

·         Clarity and coherence of the PowerPoint/presentation format – how well does it communicate the key messages?

·         Clarity, logic, and coherence (only for internal)

·         Appropriate use of media (visuals, graphs, video, colour, font, etc.)

 

·         Appropriate length, style, and format for the intended audience

o   Cues to action

o   Self-efficacy

·         4. Conduct and record the interview

·         5. Analyse the recorded interview based on the selected model. List each construct of the model and identify the relevant information gathered from your interviewee. For example, if you have selected the health belief model, findings relevant to the perceived threat might be presented as follows:

o   Perceived threats:

§  The interviewee is minimally aware of the relationship between a sedentary lifestyle and increased risk of cardiovascular disease and some cancers

§  The interviewee feels good right now and does not feel at risk of future health problems

§  The interviewee’s father has high blood pressure and early evidence of heart disease

·         6. Discuss the main factors that influence the person’s health behaviour. Substantiate this discussion with quotes from the interview; your argument should be clear and concise.

·         7. Select one component of the health behaviour that requires change and develop an educational intervention to modify it. The intervention should clearly address the interviewee’s situation. For example, if you have chosen the health belief model and want to  address  the interviewee’s perceived threat, the intervention should address interviewee’s misunderstanding or unawareness of perceived susceptibilities and severities. The educational content of the intervention should be well-summarised and brief.

·         8. Identify and discuss an appropriate communication channel to deliver the intervention to the interviewee. The selected channel should be well-justified and  align with the  interviewee’s situation.

 

Your assignment should have the following parts:

1.      Literature: A brief literature review of the health behaviour, which you have selected to improve or change (e.g., physical activity, tobacco use, unhealthy diet, alcohol use, etc.) and the health behaviour model you have selected to guide your project. This section should address: (1) why the health behaviour is important; and (2) how the selected health behaviour model can contribute to the management / prevention of the health behaviour.

Note: The literature should not include any description of the model.

2.      Method: This section should include a brief description of how the interview was conducted.

3.      Result: The interviewee’s demographic information (e.g., age, sex, highest educational level, etc.) and a summary of key findings

4.      Discussion: Bring together the relevant information about the health behaviour, clearly guided by the selected health model.

5.      Educational intervention and communication channel: The educational content, which you have developed to modify or change one of the components of the health behaviour, followed by your justification of using a particular communication channel to delivery your educational message should be reported in this section.

 

Presenting and submitting the assignment

 

Present your assignment as an essay, using the accepted format for publishable papers (see learning centre for further assistance). Do not provide a list of texts corresponding to points in the assignment outline. The total word count for the essay should not exceed 1,500 words, excluding references. The word count must be indicated on the cover sheet. Essays over the word limit will receive a lower grade.


Assessment Criteria

The assignment will be marked according to the following criteria:

·         How well is the assignment structured and presented?

Papers are to be presented in a formal structure, as you would for submission to a professional journal, for example. They will be assessed for clarity (clear, simple, grammatical language, spelling, terms explained), logical structure, coherent and logical argument, appropriate use of subheadings, clear layout, etc.

·         How effectively did you draw on the literature and the interview to identify the patient’s health beliefs?

·         How well did you critically consider the values and assumptions that underlie the interviewee’s health beliefs?

 

·         How well did you critically consider the values and assumptions that underlie your assessment practice in relation to influencing the interviewee’s health beliefs and behaviours?

Critical review of a health education intervention

Your group needs to select a health education intervention as your topic for analysis and presentation. You will be assessed for both the material your group develops, and for how creatively you present this material. Within your group, whether online or campus-based, you are required to share the tasks of finding, analysing, and interpreting the health education intervention.

 

Task Description

1.      Select one of the following behavioural risk factors:

a.       Sedentary lifestyle (physical activity)

b.      Tobacco use

c.       Unhealthy diet (obesity)

d.      Alcohol use

2.      Select an academic, refereed article on a health education intervention that has been implemented and which invites people to take responsibility for their own health. Do not choose an intervention that needs to be delivered by healthcare professionals or services (e.g., immunisation, screening, etc.). The intervention can be well or poorly designed – this is because you are required to discuss your understanding of the principles of health education and health behaviour models explored in this course.

3.      Briefly describe the intervention and then critically analyse it. Consider:

a.       Its suitability for its target group

b.      The setting

c.       Participant numbers

d.      Use of theory and/or models

e.       Its evaluation (if appropriate)

4.      Develop and support your critique by drawing on a minimum of TEN relevant academic refereed articles. Discuss:

a.       How well the intervention reflects the health education principles and health behaviour models explored in this course, justified by reference to the literature. If the intervention does not reflect the health education principles and health behaviour models:

                                                               i.      Discuss the associated implications, with reference to the literature

                                                             ii.      Suggest how the intervention might have been improved with reference to health education principles and/or health behaviour models

b.      The strengths and limitations of the intervention with reference to the literature

 

Presenting and submitting the assignment

INTERNAL

This is a 15-minute oral presentation in class, supported by a PowerPoint slide presentation or other creative format. The audience is your peers. You must choose how many of the group will participate in the oral presentation. But all members should: contribute to the research; develop the presentation; and be prepared to answer questions.

 

EXTERNAL

 

Each online group will post a presentation in the form of a PowerPoint slide presentation or other creative format on your own Moodle group space. The Course Convenor will be responsible for disseminating this to the other external groups via Moodle. For more detail on the slides, you can add explanations in the notes section of the PowerPoint slides.


Assessment Criteria

Thirty (out of 40) percentage points will be allocated for how well your group:

·         Described the intervention

·         Critically reflected on the values and assumptions that justified its development

·         Explained the conceptual and theoretical underpinnings

·         Discussed the advantages and disadvantages of the intervention

·         Discussed the implementation challenges

·         Discussed the appropriateness of the intervention to promote health within the context it was used

·         Discussed the way the intervention accounts for the needs and preferences of the target audience

·         Discussed the extent to which the intervention followed a planning process, and the connections between its objectives and its activities

 

Ten (out of 40) percentage points will be allocated for the presentation, including:

·         Clarity and coherence of the PowerPoint/presentation format – how well does it communicate the key messages?

·         Clarity, logic, and coherence (only for internal)

·         Appropriate use of media (visuals, graphs, video, colour, font, etc.)

 

·         Appropriate length, style, and format for the intended audience

contentlets.description:
This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on-campus) and fully online.

This is a six-unit general education course. It is designed to provide students from a range of disciplines with: (1) an understanding of theories and models of behaviour change; and (2) the opportunity to practice skills and strategies that impact health behavioural change. Particular emphasis is placed on improving competency in communication and decision-making to assist self and others with health concerns. With progressthrough the course, students will develop a more sophisticated level of knowledge, attitudes, values, and skills to address health issues and play an active role in enhancing their own health and that of their community. More specifically, students will gain the social, problem-solving, and communication skills necessary to manage their own health in a variety of situations.  This course is action-oriented; as such, students will be encouraged to implement and evaluate their own lifestyle choices and inspire others to optimise their wellbeing. Classes will combine lecture, discussion of the readings, case studies, real-life scenarios, presentations, small group exercises, and audiovisual materials.
